engineering_design_principles.mechanism: The use of fundamental units (Nitrogenous Bases) that store genetic information, enabling precise replication and construction of biological organisms.
The specific bonding pairs between Nitrogenous Bases (Adenine-Thymine and Guanine-Cytosine) that ensure proper base pairing and maintain the structure of the DNA double helix.
The presence of sugar-phosphate backbones on the outside of the DNA double helix, which stabilizes the structure and allows for faithful duplication of genetic information.
The ability of the DNA double helix to replicate and transmit genetic information during cell division, allowing for the creation of new organisms and the growth of existing ones.
The transcription of genetic codes into messenger RNA for protein synthesis, enabling genetic information to be used to modify and create new biological structures.
